message: Hi!
response: What is your favorite holiday?

message: one where I get to meet lots of different people.
response: What was the most number of people you have ever met during a holiday?

message: Hard to keep a count. Maybe 25.
response: Which holiday was that?

message: I think it was Australia
response: Do you still talk to the people you met?

message: Not really. The interactions are usually short-lived but it's fascinating to learn where people are coming from and what matters to them
response: Yea, me too. I feel like God often puts strangers in front of you, and gives you an opportunity to connect with them in that moment in deeply meaningful ways. Do you ever feel like you know things about strangers without them telling you?

message: what do you mean?
response: I think it's like a 6th sense, often seen as cold readings to people, but can be remarkably accurate. I once sat next to a man in a coffee and I felt a pain in my back. I asked the stranger if he had a pain. It turns out that he did in the exact spot, and said he pulled a muscle while dancing at a party. I had never met the man before and never saw him again.

message: Wow! That's interesting, borderline spooky
response: There's this practice called Treasure Hunting that's kind of a fun game you play in a public place. There's a book called The Ultimate Treasure Hunt that talks about it. You use your creativity to imagine people you will meet, and you write down a description, then you associate them with a positive message or encouraging word. Maybe you saw a teenage boy in a red hat at the shopping mall in your imagination, then while at the mall, you may find someone who matches that description. You show that you have a message for him and that you have a message for a boy in a red hat. You then give him a message of kindness or whatever was on your heart. You have no idea, sometimes you meet someone who is having a really hard day, and it brings them to tears to have a stranger show them love.

message: So, do you do treasure hunting often?
response: I did more when I was in grad school (and had more time). I would usually go with friends. For a while I would go to the farmers market in Santa Cruz every week and try to feel if there is something I am supposed to tell a stranger. Usually, they are vague hope-filled messages, but it's weird when I blurt out something oddly specific.

message: Hi!
response: Wow, hello. Can't believe we are finally talking!

message: Yeah, sorry for the long gap! I heard you took a break and were travelling around the world. How was the travel?
response: It was an interesting trip. I got to see some exotic places. For example, I hiked the Son Doong cave in Vietnam. It's the biggest and deepest cave in the world.

message: Great! Vietnam is still in my TODO bucket list. Did you also visit cambodia and other neighboring places?
response: Yes. Laos and Cambodia are the two neighboring countries. Cambodia has an exotic culture. They sell spiders, scorpions, and grasshoppers as street food! It took a lot of courage for me to try them.

message: Hehe! How long was the stay?
response: 10 days in total, and 5 of them were spent in the cave. What have I missed at work in those days?

message: Great! Good time to be back. We are still in planning phase and haven't fully aligned on the projects to tackle for next quarter.reat! Good time to be back. We are still in planning phase and haven't fully aligned on the projects to tackle for next quarter.
response: Oh, so you are already planning for the next quarter. This whole team is always living the future.

message: Hehe, yeah! It seems like the quarter is being pushed earlier than from where it starts üôÇ I like these planning sessions. It makes me feel more confident about the work I am doing.
response: Yeah. Some people underestimate the importance of planning, but I think it's very important to have the correct plan. Executing the wrong plan is terrible. Also, planning is fun. You can stack up so many ideas and get great feedbacks.

message: True! I think we should set aside some time to discuss some project details? Does tomorrow afternoon work for you?
response: Yeah tomorrow afternoon works for me. Let me set a time on your calendar. Is 3pm good?

message: Okay. See tomorrow then.

response: What do you think are the big advantages? Like personal assistants?

message: I think it can take many different forms as a product. The research implication is also huge! It will signify how AI research has progressed so far and better place to tackle more futuristic problems üôÇ Sort of like stepping on the moon üôÇ I might be overselling it here üòõ
response: No, I agree -- it's such an exciting time to be alive to get to witness all this and be a part of it. I wonder if I'll be able someday to get a chatbot to just auto-suggest conversations for me

response: Same with you!

message: Hi!
response: Do you believe in miracles?

message: Lol. No. I know too many people whose lives suck.
response: Should we be helping them, so it sucks less?\

message: It's too many of them out there. You help who you can. Regardless, I wouldn't say I believe in miracles - well, if I got promoted next cycle I might change my mind.
response: Haha... Well, it sounds like career is really important to you. What matters to you the most in life?

message: Right now, not much. It's unclear. Career is a good fallback because you get told what good means and you act accordingly. I haven't gone through the process of shaping my values. What about you?
response: I'd say that I want to live for the best possible world in my lifetime. It's probably a result of my playing too many video games as a child.

message: We didn't have electricity growing up. Explains a lot. Lol.
response: Does not having had electricity help you empathize more with people of differing backgrounds and/or makes you feel a bit a distance from those who don't understand?

message: It makes it easier to empathise with people who grew up lacking things. Not sure it makes me empathise with people in general. Where did you grow up?
response: I grew up in the United States, but my parents were immigrants and ended up being scammed of all their money, so we moved to Taiwan to live with family for a little bit.

message: ALL THEIR MONEY? By a person or an organisation?
response: I was kind of too young to really understand, but apparently there are people who scam Asian immigrants into investing in their own restaurant business. I know that the other part of it was that my mom got sick/hospitalized, and we didn't have insurance. To be honest, I don't really know what really happened versus what my parents want people to think. I just know that one minute I was in the US, and then they put me on a plane to Taiwan, and I never saw my stuff again. In some ways, it made me more sentimental. Would you say you are more grounded and practical as a result of your background?

message: that's great. It's so cold these nights. Right setting for hot coco. Do you have anything you enjoy doing during cold times?
response: Traveling to warm places haha. When it's cold, you appreciate the warm climate more üôÇ If I am not traveling, then I prefer there to be snow on the ground so I can go skiing or tubing down the mountain. What about you?

message: I tuck in blankets and read a book lol. I have never done tubing, but I seen some people do it. Is it worth it if you already ski?
response: Skiing involves a lot of muscle - especially in the legs so it is a workout. Tubing, you just sit and enjoy the ride down. Also with tubing, you can chain with your friends and go down together whereas with skiing, you're trying to not run into your friends.

message: hahaha that's a great way to put it
response: You should definitely try tubing the next time you head towards the mountains during the winter!

message: Yeah. I'll try to get a group together. ttyl!
response: See ya!

message: Hi!
response: Hello there!

message: How has your morning been thus far?
response: Its alright. Went grocery shopping and got to stroll around in the rain. How about you?

message: Today is a work day! How did you have time for that? I'm going through a lot right now.
response: Oh, you mean going through a lot of work? I usually take Wednesdays off because I work the weekends!

message: WHAT? Why would you do that? Take the least interesting day of the week off and work on the most interesting?
response: I actually don't have a choice. I'm an acupuncturist and all my clients want to be treated on the weekend!

message: Wow. The game is brutal like that. I've always been sceptical of acupuncture. Like...does it even work? Why? How? Where is the literature?
response: I went to school for it and so I find the literature quite convincing. I've also seen its benefits firsthand in my practice. It revolves around the Chinese notion of Qi.

message: Lol. Bro...I don't buy it unless it has a paper that was presented at a conference and peer reviewed by 6 independent parties. Who wrote the literature? Where did it originate?
response: Haha. All good questions! I don't have studies on hand at the moment, but perhaps I can send some to you later! What do you do for work?

message: I'm a comic.
response: Oh wow! What's your best joke?

message: It's not appropriate to say here but I assure you it's VERY funny.
response: Haha fantastic

message: Hi!
response: Oh hey. How's your day been?

message: It's good! Just went to the park to enjoy the sun. You?
response: The sun is a bit too bright for more. Maybe I'm on the verge of becoming a vampire.

message: Haha, beach season is coming! You need to look tan! What did you do indoors all day?
response: I mostly work. Sometimes I try looking at at beach photos and pretending that I'm actually going to the beach.

message: hahahaha, that's pretty funny. Ever thought of bringing your work things to the beach??
response: All the times. My work involves a few types of fish and a few types of nets. I just put the nets on the fish to see how the fish will react. Every time I do that, I think of going to the beach.

message: Hmm I see. It sounds like you work near the water already, no? Are you some kind of fish researcher?
response: Yes that's close. My research focuses on jellyfish and pufferfish. Many of them a poisonous, but if processed correctly, they would make hi-end foods. I try to find the best recipes to bring these fish to the tables.

message: Woah! This is very interesting! I have honestly never heard of such kind of work. Is it dangerous at all?
response: Yes and no. Because it's obviously dangerous, we all have to wear protective clothes. Thus, accidents almost never happen.

message: Hmmm, yes I have heard that. Apparently most mountain climbers fall not on the most dangerous routes, but on the easier routes, when their guard is down! Sounds like the same psychological phenomenon.
response: Yes, it's the same philosophy. You seem to know a lot about mountain climbing. Do you climb a lot?

message: I'm pretty amateur! I like to climb at indoor climbing gyms and have never gone outside on dangerous routes actually. Ever tried it yourself?
response: I climb very occasionally. My fingertips are not strong enough so I never make too much progress.

message: Hi!
response: hi, what's up!

response: yea I'm travelling to Vancouver this weekend. what about you? üôÇ

message: Cool. Which conference? I saw on Twitter the other day, some people saying they were denied visas for some conference in Canada. Perhaps it's the same one. I really liked this place called Kingyo. It has good Japanese food if you're into that.
response: yea it's <REDACTED_TERM>, the largest machine learning conference. I'll check out Kingyo, do we need to make reservation in advance?

message: I don't recall. My friend was hosting me and did all the leg work. Do you know any people in the area?
response: hmm not the local people but there will be tons of people at the conference üôÇ
